captions.text:
Jackson, I haven't
slept in three days.

My cat keeps me
up all night long.
I'm gonna kill her.

No, I'm not gonna kill her,
but Jackson, you gotta tell me.
I'm gonna kill myself here.

Tell me, how do I sleep
through the night?
And I say, oh, that one?
That's easy.

So let me ask you
something, people.
You ready to get cat-ified?
Let's go!

As you have noticed
I'm sure, this
is not exactly the cat cave.
It is a cave.
It's a little echoey in here.

But no, I am in a hotel room
in San Diego, California,

where we are wrapping
up filming the season

of "My Cat from
Hell" season five,

premiering-- coming
up in the spring.

Do stay tuned because
you'll find out

everything you have to know
about the premier of "My Cat

from Hell" here, on
the Cat Daddy channel.
Just, you know, stay tuned.

So today we're
talking about what?

Your cat allowing you to
sleep through the night.

Now, the last
episode I was talking

about the concept of
circadian rhythms,

a cat's 24 hour clock,
and how naturally it

wants to get them
up at dusk and dawn.

We can help guide
their circadian rhythm.
We can reset their body clocks.

But there's a couple of
really important things.

Now when last we met I
also gave you homework,

and that homework
was about making sure

that you established a daily
rhythm, that you establish

rituals that happen
throughout the day that
helps keep their body going.

And the one thing that is
most important to what we're

going to do right now is
they're feeding schedule.

Remember something,
if you allow your cats

to graze all day
long, if you allow

them to eat whenever
they want to eat,

then not only do you not
have a chance of affecting

their behavior
even a little bit,

but you're not
allowing their body

to process food in
the natural way.

They're constantly in
this arc of digestion.

And we don't want that
because then their energy
is totally unpredictable to us.

Here's what I would
ask you to do.
If you free feed, make it stop.

The next step is, you
bring in meal time.

Real big change in a cat's life
is not met with nice things.

And you do not want to
encourage bad behavior,

and by making rapid changes
like that, you kind of are.

We'll keep the dry food
out, but then every day you
just put less and less in there.

And by the end of that first
week that, there is food

down there, they don't feel
like they're missing anything.

But by an hour after
you leave for work,

they've polished it off and
now they're waiting for a meal.
Now here's the rule of thumb.

I would like to see no
longer than between six

and eight hours you
can make it happen.

So you're feeding
three meals a day

and then your cat's
energy is coming up
to meet those meal times.

And I guarantee you,
within a week or two

of instituting this meal
time, your cat's energy

will come up to
meet your schedules.

Your second step
is to try to get
them to go to sleep when you do.

Let's say your bed
time is 11 o'clock.
OK.

So by 9:30 you should be
feeding your last meal.

But you don't want to
do that in a vacuum.

In the past-- you know me-- we
have been talking about hunt,
catch, kill, eat.
Right?
And so that means playtime.

That means you have a
really nice, chunky play

time right before
that last meal.

You bring them to a
boil during play time.
You get them just pooped out.

Then you let them come
down for a second.

Again, all cats have the
second wind, the third wind.

Cats are built for
speed, not for distance.

So bring them to a boil,
let them come down.

Bring them to a
boil, now it's going

to take less time for
them to get worn out.

Now less time, now
they're tired, right?
When they pooped out, boom.
Now, hunt, catch, kill, eat.
Feed their last meal of the day.
What comes after eat?
Groom.
Yeah, baby.

We're all about getting
clean right now.
And then sleep.
And then you go to sleep.

Now we're getting
to the hard part.

Because now you've got
to do some serious work.

So now it's 3 o'clock
in the morning,
and your cat is waking you up.

But you know, I gave you
a meal at 11 o'clock.
I wore you down at 9:30.

You should be down for the
count right now, but you're not.
Now here's the tough part.

I mean, I'm laughing
only because I

know how ridiculously
hard this is.

What you've got to do at
3 o'clock in the morning,
your cat's driving you crazy.
You ignore them.
You ignore them completely.
Completely.

And you definitely don't get
up, feed them, walk around,

go to the bathroom,
come back again.
You don't play with them.
Nothing.
You ignore them completely.
Because that is payoff.

Negative attention, positive
attention, any attention
whatsoever is still attention.

You have to
extinguish the payoff.

If you tell them
night after night

after night that nothing's
going to happen when they

do that certain behavior,
that behavior will stop.

So people, what that means
is that for about 10 days

to two weeks, it may be
really, really long nights.
Don't kill me.
Now, if it goes past 13 nights?
Whatever, come find me.

Because I'm telling
you, it won't happen.

In conclusion, let's
give you some homework.
Take a look at that blackboard.
Now, write it down here.

First thing you do
is change your cat

from free-feeders
to meal-feeders.
Big change.

Next thing you do is you feed
in conjunction with play.

Third thing, remember
that your cat's energy
moves with your energy.

So remember that you're trying
to merge the two together.

Your energy, your cat's energy,
your clock, your cat's clock,
merge them together.

Then don't forget, the last
meal of the day an hour
and a half before you go to bed.

You're going to hunt, catch,
kill, eat, let them groom
and sleep until you go to bed.
Boom.
Then we get through the night.

And then the last step, folks--
the last, most important step
is, ignore them.
You guys can do this.

You can affect your
cat's body clock,
and that's how you do it.

That's how you sleep
through the night.
Boom.
Consider yourself cat-ified.
Alright.
Let's wrap this up.

Hey folks, if you're trying
to find me, I'm easily found.

Take a look at Facebook
and Instagram and Twitter
and YouTube and Google+.

And don't forget,
speaking of Google+,

every month we do Live
from the Cat Cave.

And that is a live
Google Hangout.

This month I'm just going to be
doing live question and answer.
That will be a lot of fun.

In the meantime, folks,
take care of yourself.
Take care of your cats.

And all light, all
love, all mojo to you.
THEME SONG: You're a bad cat.
I'm not a bad cat.
You're a bad cat.
I'm not a bad cat.
You're a bad cat.
I'm just misunderstood.
Meow.

title: Train Your Cat to Let You Sleep

comments.text:
My cat won't play with toys, so it's impossible to tire her out :( She also 
won't come out from under the bed if anyone else is awake in the house, 
even though I keep her in my room with the door shut﻿
comments.author: elmobabe979

comments.text:
Hi! Im a fan of you i like cats too! Im just a kid but my parents give my 
cat fish at wednesday and sunday in the morning but then when the fish is 
finished my parents give him normal food at 10.00 am but one time mu cat 
was scratching my sister's pillow then i suddenly i look at the clock it is 
2.20 am.but i wasnt mad at him i pet him for a while i he purred then i 
went back to sleep. Then when i woke up at the side of my hair there is 
some fur on my hair!lol﻿

comments.text: Wow this is long but i hope you read!
comments.author: Siti Rabiatul Adawiyah Bahar

comments.text:
My big, beautiful boy wakes me up at all hours of the night, but mostly at 
around 4:00, because he wants to eat. We only feed our cats twice a day at 
the same times. He jumps up on my bed and eats my hair. I just pull the 
covers over my face, and he goes away.﻿
comments.author: TheMadameHannah

comments.text:
My cat sleeps in his own room.. he gets ridiculous sometimes and lies up 
against the door trying to make me let him out.. instead I pick him up and 
put him on his bed and nicely but strictly tell him to go to bed. at first 
he was not so cool with it but now I actually think he likes it when I put 
him into his bed hahaha he looks at me like he is super tired and he goes 
to bed. maybe he is a little crazy or maybe I am﻿
comments.author: Stef Rose (Stef's Games)

comments.text: great advice!﻿
comments.author: user150786

comments.text:
Hello Jackson galaxy I'm having a problem with one of my Himalayan timid 
cat every time I start a shave she goes crazy at me and becomes very wild 
and bites me.
I tried the towel covering her head and managed to trim her back and tail 
but because shes biting i cant do her neck and paws any suggestion in  this 
situation?
I don't want to make her hate me and she sheds allot and gets matted fur 
all over her body....
please help out ...
urs truly shamsa﻿
comments.author: shamsa M.

comments.text:
Wow. Tiring her out before bed really works! She slept like a log all 
night!﻿
comments.author: MandarinCat

comments.text:
We have a small dog + cat. We let them free-graze during the day for weight 
management. Past pets taught me that when you regulate their meals they 
just get into starve-n-stuff mode. They'll gorge on the food then lay 
around for hours. They just learn that food is scarce (only shows up at 
specific times in specific quantities) so stuff up while you can. Grazing 
teaches them that food scarcity is not a problem, so they nibble and burn 
off what they eat as they go instead of turning into a fat storing gorge.

However, our cat was definitely a pain to get to sleep the first couple of 
months. Ironically, it was mostly the dog that taught him to sleep on a 
schedule. Kitty loves playing with the dog, but the dog needs to sleep at 
night and take some naps. He got snippy with kitty a couple of times when 
trying to sleep for the cat to realize not to bother him when he's sleepy. 
Then kitty learned to just nap at the same time. So, they both sleep though 
the night, are up at morning to play and eat, take a midmorning nap 
together in the sun, play in the afternoon, evening nap, more play then 
bed. Maybe we got lucky.﻿
comments.author: therandomdot

comments.text:
Hey Jackson, would the Feed Times work with my brain damaged epilepsy cat? 
we tried doing the two meals a day, but she forgets she's been fed and then 
meows the entire day and doesnt stop!﻿
comments.author: Kire Moonchild

comments.text:
THANK YOU. This is just what I needed to know.
When I turn off the lights to go to sleep, my kitten climbs on the bed and 
snuggles next to me. But after some time, in the middle of the night, she's 
not tired anymore and starts jumping around the bed and playing. It doesn't 
let me sleep. :I If I ignore her long enough, she goes to sleep again. But 
her nap times are so short and she starts to play again. ;^;﻿
comments.author: MandarinCat

comments.text:
hi Jackson:). i have a pretty specific problem with one of my cats. he is 
awfully vocal. sometimes he just walks through the house yowling, looking 
at walls meowing or staring at you screaming, not even seeming to want 
anything. he has been doing this since he was little but his voice is 
getting stronger and now his constant "talking" can be heard by neighbours 
too. I just dont know what to do anymore. plus he is not even bothered by 
being ignored, he just keeps on meowing. he is fixed too.﻿
comments.author: petra starmuller

comments.text:
My husband's cat is synced to my husband's schedule, to the point she wakes 
me up when he's on the road for work - 4 in the morning. And at 4 on 
weekends, too. And she goes NUTS if I don't go to bed at the same time he 
does every night, too. Even when he's not home. I'm so used to it now, my 
internal clock has changed.﻿

comments.text:
i just leave him outside the room..he meows for a couple minutes begging to 
get in, but then he stops.﻿

comments.text: The 3am cat with the party hat & horn cracked me up.﻿

comments.text: My Cat Likes to Sleep with Me﻿

comments.text:
I just pretend I'm still asleep, then she leaves me for a bit longer. Ha 
Ha. I still get a wet nose to the eye, before she leaves me again. So 
greedy, there's dry food downstairs, and yet it's all about the wet food 
meal. I do love long sleeps. She goes to bed the same time as me.﻿
comments.author: Sas Flowers

comments.text:
Hello Jackson, today my family and I bought a new kitten and she is too 
 energetic when the rest of us want to go to bed. So at first we put her in 
the carrier/cage, then she began to meow non-stop so we decided to put her 
in a dark separate room by herself with her essentials (litterbug, food, 
water etc.) and that seemed to have done the trick in the short term but I 
have a feeling that my kitten will resent me for it in the future. Am I 
right to feel this way or is this just a superstition. A reply would be 
much appreciated.﻿
comments.author: rayquaza44

comments.text:
Hi Jackson,
     My 2 cats,Sam and Spice and I live in a unfinished cabin in the rain 
forest on Hawaii island. That being said, it is not uncommon at night, that 
an uninvited visitor  finds its way inside the cabin.
      When they do, the cats true natures kicks in and then it's hunt,catch 
kill, and sometimes eat [prey]. I frequently hear Sam running around in the 
kitchen running down something that has gotten in during the night.
 When they haven't acquired their own breakfast I get a soft pat, pat on my 
cheek between 5:30-6:00am. They share a can of '9 Lives' wet food and do 
not ask for the scoop of dry food until 6:30-8:00 pm.They let me sleep 
without disturbing me. In the past, I ignored them when they would try to 
wake me up during the night.
Jackson, due keep those great videos coming my way. So far,I have watched 
all of them.﻿

comments.text: This tips worked for me and my kitty! :)﻿

comments.author: NappyMapp _

comments.text:
We have never been able to leave food out so we're already doing that. Our 
issue is our one of our two 11 month old kittens will NOT settle down to 
sleep.  He jumps all over me, loves playing with my hair, pouncing on my 
face or climbing up inside my pajama pants!  His brother is totally calm & 
loves snuggling and would probably sleep all night with us.  After an hour 
of not sleeping I always have to bring them both in the basement to sleep 
(which our 17 year old cat really appreciates because they won't leave him 
alone either!).  I'm guessing we just have to keep trying this and maybe 
have a few sleepless nights.  Maybe if we give them what we call "the 
midnight snack" a little earlier & not right before our bedtime that could 
help too.  Good tips!!!﻿

omg... that people with cats wonders about this surprises me. If you have a 
cat and you know their behavior issin't it obvious that they will stop 
doing something when you ignore them? When my cat was doing this it came 
sraching on my window, (i only feed mine three times a day.. if i don't it 
gets fat) but I got it.. by myself. If you ignore behavior the behavior

comments.text:
So lets see if I understood...
do excersice with them before feed them, and then give them the meal?﻿
comments.author: Diaablo Maldonado

comments.text:
I swear to god my cat is the most stubborn cat in the history of the world. 
She gets meals 3 times a day- before school, after school, before I go to 
sleep. After school work, play time (round half an hour). Then food, obvs. 
Afterwards, I groom her. Then it's time for "sleep." As in I lay awake for 
half an hour listening to her try to meow and jump her way into my bedroom 
(and with sticky tape on the handle)! I would let her in to sleep with me, 
but I have allergies that only show up severely when I'm around cats in a 
close proximity for more than like 8 hours (don't ask, discovered it when 
at a sleepover at a friend's house. Her 6 cats have the run of the place). 
Eventually she'll quiet and go to sleep, but at around 3 to 5 AM she'll 
start again and won't stop until morning. Every. Single. Day. It's gotten 
to the point where I've actually accidentally trained myself to sleep 
through her meows, but my mom can't, and it's driving her insane, 
especially the fact that she has to ignore her. ﻿

comments.text: Sorry

comments.text:
You have a good channel. Your advice is expert , too. I agree with what 
you're saying, but I never knew this at the time. Now she's getting old and 
hasn't got a real hunting drive anymore. However,  she has been sleeping in 
bed with me since she was young, and as long as I'm in bed she is as well. 
Except for the middle of the night. I don't get up, if she does, and I 
"pretend sleep".  After a bite, she comes back to bed. Yeah, never did the 
mealtimes.. but we certainly have a routine, and I never add new food in 
the middle of the night. Still, if I had any problem with conflicting 
schedules,  I most likely would attempt this advice.. THX.﻿

and if its up it dosent bother me it just waits I dont even have to ignore

comments.author: Ankka-Senpai

comments.text:
my cat walks over me sometimes when I sleep or starts grooming me which is 
a bit of a annoyance feeling a sandpaper tongue on your forehead while you 
sleep but I leave a lot of toys laying around so she can amuse herself if 
she gets bored. Usually when I get into bed she goes in her little house by 
my bed and starts sleeping. She gets a big annoying when I have to wake up 
or if she is hungry.﻿
comments.author: Paul

comments.text:
I work at Home Depot where unfortunately we are not allowed a set schedule. 
I know crazy right !!!  Well I work any day of the week any where from 5am 
to 12am ... yep and sometimes after midnight too. So my poor Bella girl is 
up and down with me and my comings and goings from home. ( she is strictly 
and indoor girl ! ) My husband on the other hand is a 6am to 9 or 10pm kind 
of guy. So she, Bella gets into trouble with him a lot !! Because she is 
awake at 3am , and she does want to play when nobody is home so she will 
make a mess of things ..... nothing terrible though. Sometimes when she has 
been alone to long she gets so excited to see us she will get a little 
aggressive and depending on how you respond will determine how that will 
play out. I am afraid I wont be able to talk my husband out of getting rid 
of her one of these times. We moved about 2 yrs ago too and ever since we 
have been here, she is super nervous and jumpy about sounds ..... I thought 
she would have calmed down and gotten used to this place by now ??  Any 
suggestions to try ??﻿
comments.author: Chryl Garot

comments.text: I am hoping this works because I am dying from lack of sleep! :)﻿

comments.text: Three times a day?﻿
comments.author: Neequu78

comments.text:
My family's bed times are all different so this is really difficult. My 
sisters want to feed my fur babies at 10:30 and put them to bed, but I 
don't get to go to bed until 6:00 AM which is, unfortunately, when they 
wake up. -_- I live in a household of 7 people. My husband and I are EMT's. 
Suggestions? How can we get on the same page?﻿
comments.author: Shannon hubbard

comments.text:
My cat sleeps fine at night, as long as I'm awake too. He wants me to stay 
awake and watch him sleep... maybe to keep a look out for predators... or 
maybe just to pet his belly while he sleeps? It used to be that from 8pm to 
8am, he would lay on me. If I got up, he'd usually not try to to hold me 
down, sometimes he would but he'd follow me around until I laid down again 
then would climb on my belly again. This lasted for the first 2 years. O.O

 The last few months though, he's been sleeping elsewhere for long periods 
of times. He'll come and stand on my chest and stick his nose in my face if 
I fall asleep. Just stand there, staring. In the dark. I'd try to ignore 
him or wrap my arm around him and roll over or something.... he would 
continue to just stay and stare. Or occasionally try to smother me with his 
neck whilst laying his chin on my head. I have narcolepsy, so automatic 
functions can be triggered in my sleep. He figured that one out, and now 
I'll wake up and realize I'm cradling a giant cat like a baby and rubbing 
his belly in my sleep. Hard to ignore him when he's learned how to 
manipulate my sleep disorder. 

He's actually not my cat, technically. I'm not allowed to have pets. He's 
kind of a stray that adopted me. During the day, he's out running around 
playing outside in the little wooded area on the property. At night, I 
sneak him in and snuggle the hell out of him. I make sure he's fed, 
watered, vet bills taken care of. Would totally adopt him and have him as 
in indoor cat if I could. Anyway, everyone in the apartments look out for 
him, so I'm not too worried. I generally sleep during the day anyway, 
because of my sleep disorder... but now it's become almost a necessity, 
because if I fall asleep at night, he'll either manipulate my sleep 
disorder or he'll try to smother me under his fur or he'll smack me in the 
face or stand on my chest, staring creepily. If I'm awake, he'll happily 
lay on my belly and fall asleep and stay asleep all night if I were to not 
move. If I fall asleep though... it's game on. ﻿
comments.author: Bunny

comments.text:
my cat use to wake me up at 10:00 every day, and before I watched this, I 
did ignore her, and she never did it again﻿

comments.text:
I had a cat literally eat a hole through my bedroom door from ignoring her. 
 I would put her outside my room to sleep because she tended to attack my 
feet, and I would sometimes kick her if I was too asleep to realize that 
the claws in my foot were hers.  So through several weeks of scratching and 
biting the door, she now has a hole that she can come and go as she pleases 
through.﻿
comments.author: Kitche Vadimas

comments.text: what the heck is your door made of? a slice of bread?!
comments.author: Iris E

comments.text:
I have to disagree with Jackson on mealtimes. Cats in the wild (see the 
African wildcat) subsist on small prey like rodents and birds. That's 3-5 
meals a day. I have watched my own cats visiting the feeder at such 
intervals. Also rescued cats often have anxiety about food and do far 
better with free feeding.
The biggest thing is to not reward them when they try to wake you, and put 
food out at bedtime.﻿
comments.author: PraiseDivineMercy

comments.text: My kitty wakes me up at like 4am to get rubbed 😒😑﻿
comments.author: Just an Arianator

comments.text:
I sleep during the morning hours because I work at night. It took a long 
time to get my cat used to this. I had to lock him out of my room in the 
morning and he would scratch the carpet and whine. He behaves better now 
because he is used to the routine. ﻿
comments.author: Merry Joy Hayes

comments.text:
It SOUNDS so easy! Problem is that when I do try to ignore her she BITES 
me! The more I ignore, the more she bites and the harder it gets!!! So I am 
afraid I now have the routine of getting up at least once, if not twice. 
Thing is, she usually HAS food in her plate and water in her dish - I think 
she just wants me up. I end up giving her 'time out' until morning. Is that 
wrong? (Unfortunately I live in South Africa so I can't get you to come to 
my home!!!!)﻿
comments.author: Felicity Mason

comments.text:
In my experience, locking them out just results in crying and serious 
damage to the carpet just outside the door
comments.author: PraiseDivineMercy

comments.text:
Lock her out of your room! Biting is a no-go area, and she should not have 
the opportunity.
comments.author: Trixinator

comments.text:
I have the same problem with my cat Toby. I have effected some improvement 
in two ways:
1) More play time. I think it lets out the aggression
2) My cats sleep with me. If Toby tries nipping I roll over and give him a 
big hug in a way he does not like. I also put my hand around the scruff of 
his neck like a mother cat disciplines her kittens. Basic idea: always 
respond to the biting by being an annoying PITA in a way that does not harm 
them.
comments.author: PraiseDivineMercy

comments.text:
Ok Jackson, what do I do?  My cat is on a feeding schedule, and has been 
since we got him, but lately (he's now almost 4 years old).  he'll eat and 
be hyper, so I come to play with him, and he won't have anything to do with 
his cat toy, or laser pointer, and if he does, he'll just chase it for 
short distances, and then not show interest (no matter how much I tease him 
with the light or toy).  It's like he's bored with it.  I tried new toys 
and it doesn't seem to make a difference.  When he was 2, he'd jump after 
the toys, and really propel himself high to get it.  now I don't see him do 
that anymore.  What am I doing wrong?  Or is it just old age on his part?  
I never can get him panting either, no matter how hard I try.  Please give 
me some advice.﻿
comments.author: Bertminator

comments.text: I don't know about Felicity's cat, but mine is indoor cat only.
comments.author: Bertminator

comments.text:
Don't worry - cats are first children, then teenagers (the first 2 years 
are hell), then they begin adulthood and settle down after they are 3 or 4. 
Yes, they can have kitten already when they are 1 year old, but they are 
still kids, so don't let that fool you (after all, there are plenty of 
teenage pregnancies in the human world...) so back to the point: Your cat 
is growing up. If he is a little bit less active but otherwise healthy, 
it's ok. Once they are 6 or 7 they will want to sleep most of the time 
anyway. If however your cat loses all interest, stops grooming himself, and 
becomes apathetic, of course there is something wrong and you need to take 
him to the vet. If not, don't panic, try new toys, and try to adjust to the 
schedule of when he's in play mood and when he isn't.
One question: Is he a house cat or free range? Because free range cats have 
seasonal activity - in spring they jump to action, and in winter they 
almost hibernate. House cats have the seasonal thing a little less 
pronounced. But my cats, after spending 3 months behind my wood stove 
sleeping, just brought me 3 birds home in 2 weeks. It's spring.
comments.author: Trixinator

comments.text:
Here's a small tip for you, I just witnessed my cat actually jumping at a 
long lost forgotten toy that he loved.  Maybe if you can find one your cat 
will thrive with it also.  I usually tie it up with a good fishing line, as 
the line it comes with is pretty weak, but this is what it looks like 
http://www.officeplayground.com/Assets/ProductPreview/pi2700-2899/2845_magicworm_1b.jpg  
I bought mine at "Dollarama" here in Canada, anid it's only $1.00, and 
comes in 3 or 4 colors.  My kitty loved it today, got him to jump a good 6 
or 7 times.

 The oldest is 16 and still acts like a youngster.  ﻿

free environment for sleep.﻿

Hey Jackson thanks a lot! How do I ignore my kitten (3-4months old) whilst

comments.author: melissaclissold

comments.text:
If the kitten wakes you up every night, you should try to keep it in 
another room during the night. If it starts meowing to get your attention 
instead, you should just ignore it for a couple of weeks, and it will stop 
eventually :)
comments.author: Nomenklatur :

comments.text:
Jackson, I am completely on board with your suggestions on how to "train" 
my cat(s) to let me sleep and I'm happy to tell you that I am on board with 
all of your suggestions regarding getting the cats circadian rhythm set, 
but my situation is a bit unique.  I have 2 cats, a 6 yr old female that 
have been getting a small amount of wet food at breakfast time and then 
they are free-fed Purina Cat Chow for the remainder of the day.  The female 
hasn't been overeating and when she was the only cat in the house, a small 
bowl of dry food would last her 2 days.  Now that the male cat is sharing 
the same food, I'm having to fill a much larger bowl with the dry food 
every day and sometimes twice a day so that the male gets enough to satisfy 
his appetite AND leaves enough for the female too.  The biggest reasons why 
I have always fed these cats and others I had in the past dry food was 
because it was what most everybody fed cats AND because it was more 
affordable than wet.  I'm a little concerned that I may not be able to 
afford to feed my cats if I switch to wet food only.    First because I 
don't know how much is suggested by the manufacturer for each cat.  I know 
that they consider things like the age,weight and gender of the cats you're 
trying to feed, but the bottom line is the wet food doesn't go nearly as 
far and it costs quite a bit more than dry food. Plus aren't cats supposed 
to have some dry food in their diet?  I've been told that they need it to 
help clean their teeth sort of like milk bones for dogs.  Can anyone help 
shed some light on this issue for me?  I want to get started feeding my 
cats the right way so that they will stop being so needy and keeping me 
awake at night and/or waking me way too early in the morning.  Oh, and one 
more question too........how am I supposed to just ignore my cats if they 
choose to bother me at night when I'm trying to sleep?  My cats don't just 
simply meow and run around my bedroom making noise.  They like to crawl all 
over me and one does this thing where its like she's giving me a massage. 
 I lovingly refer to it as she's "making biscuits"!  Like a kitten would do 
when still trying to get milk from the mother cat.  Sounds like it would 
feel kind of good, but at 3 or 4 am, trust me, its a pain in the butt and 
it wakes you up just the same.  The male cat rummages around in my bedroom 
and crawls under the bed and attempts to get under the covers, attacking 
anything he thinks he saw move and climbs up on my computer tower desk and 
tall dresser where all my expensive electronics are and tries to catch the 
fish in a small fish tank that I have on the top of my desk too.  I'm 
afraid that if I don't do something to deter him from doing these things, 
he might just end up breaking something or splashing enough water out of 
the fish tank and all over my desk and computer.  Worse yet what if he 
managed to tip over the fish tank or my computer monitor or tv (it's just a 
small 19" flat screen)?  He's a very rambunctious 13 lb 9 month old who has 
no fear and to him this nightly haunting is just a game.  I know I have to 
start somewhere, but I fear that to simply ignore him when he's hell bent 
on getting fed on his terms could be extremely costly and even dangerous or 
hazardous to his health.  Not to mention, what it could do to my mental 
well being or job security if he did manage to ruin my computer desk or 
worse my work computer and the data files it contains!  So sorry to all of 
you who have to read this rambling of mine.  I'm aware that this is much 
more than a "comment".  It's just I need to solve this issue before I go 
nuts and I had more questions than I could find the answers for in going 
thru all of the many video responses here in the pages of great info on 
this site!  Any advice that anyone can offer would be truly appreciated. ﻿
comments.author: Tanya Adamson

comments.text:
Will this diet change, schedule change work with a 17 year old female.  I 
hesitate to disrupt her lifestyle at this delicate stage of her life.  She 
does wake me up, pissing me off, but I'm very happy she's still around to 
bug me.  She's great the rest of the day.﻿

comments.text:
Hi! 

So, I got given a beautiful kitten for Christmas- a male moggy named 
"Satchel". He's now 12 weeks old. He is so lovely to have around. My only 
issues is that he is incredibly clingy- if I go anywhere, he follows me and 
if I go to use the bathroom, he cries loudly outside the door! I know he's 
going to be a bit clingy, as I'm his new Mum and he's still a baby.. What I 
wanted to ask was, you say the best thing to do when your kitty wakes you 
up, playing is to ignore them. I try my best, but as Satchel is on my bed, 
sometimes he climbs under the covers and nips me, or gets me with his 
claws. i know he isn't doing it to be mean, but what can I do to prevent 
this?

Thanks :-)﻿
